notes: By whakapapa, the best person to say these names would have been a descendent of Chief Te Awe Awe, and a daughter of his was insistant that it should be so, but none of his children spoke the language. (In fact Te Awe Awe had lived a double life, going by an English name and playing in a jazz band.) Eventually she relented, and Matawhā "Pompey" Durie, father of Judge Eddie and Dr Mason Durie, said them, and he was amply qualified to do so.
Mr Mareikura was very frail when I recorded him, and died soon after. I went to the aftermath of his tangi, and secured the permission of his family to use the recording nonetheless.

Before I recorded any Taupō names, I consulted Sir Hepi Te Heu Heu, who took me to morning tea in Taumarunui. He very modestly declined to speak, but recommended those who did, each of whom was excellent.
I have often played this track to illustrate the beauty of the Māori language and its placenames.

Within seconds of receiving the David Toft grant to begin recording Ngā Ingoa ō Aotearoa in January 1984, someone (Pākehā) was dogmatically telling me the WH in Whanganui must be pronounced FW, The first printed volume spelt Wanganui without an H as the name of the zone and in parentheses for the city, and this was almost universal until David Young's article "River of great waiting" in NZ Geographic 003, July-September 1989. Elders asked him to spell it with the H, and the game was afoot. It arose again when the official spelling of the river and region was being considered in 2009. (It wss then that I hit on the superscript <sup>h</sup> as a way of cutting the Gordian knot.) Currently either spelling is officially acceptable. Attempting to pronounce the H has played havoc with the pronunciation by non-speakers of Māori. The local Māori pronunciation leaves the H almost (but not quite) silent, and the common pronunciation (and hence spelling) with no H at all was a near-approximation. This has become the most contentious (and one of the least important) issues in saying Māori placenames.

I had very much hoped to record the voice of Titi Tihu for the upper Wʰanganui river. I tracked him down, driving along the centre of the road towards Tawataʰa. Aged in his 90s, he spoke only Māori, and my reo was not up to the task explaining my mission and talking him into speaking. The names were instead spoken by his nephew in something of a hurry, in a room overlooking a busy Taumarunui street (perhaps they aren't usually, but this one was).

I learnt something about Māori diplomacy in drawing the boundaries of this Zone. Ruka Broughton told me that a handful of names I had given him near the bank of the Whanganui River belonged to Whanganui iwi. I consulted the Whanganui elders and they said no, they belong to Ruka's iwi, Ngā Rauru. When I want back to him, he said "I knew that, but I wanted them to say it." This is the only Zone I can say with confidence corresponds to a rohe-ā-iwi.

Ruka Broughton (Sr) was ideally qualified to say the names of this region, which closely corresponds to the rohe of his people Ngā Rauru (Kītahi), "Ngā Rauru of the Single Word". Only in the east was there an issue. Some names close to the Wʰanganui river might have belonged to the people of the river. At Ruka's direction, I went back to the Wʰanganui elders and was told, no, they belong to Ngā Rauru. Ruka said "I knew they did, but I wanted them to say it." - a beautiful example of Māori diplomacy, one of many I experienced in my travels.
About 30 seconds into this track, at Kiorenui, a fly goes around the microphones. People listening on headphones often try to swat it away.

Auckland has a rich vein of historial names that are no longer current, or have been modified over time. Thus it became useful to divide it into "ancient" (to approximately the mid-19th century) and "modern".

Auckland has a rich vein of historial names that are no longer current, or have been modified over time. Thus it became useful to divide it into "ancient" (to approximately the mid-19th century) and "modern".
The "ancient" list is intended to be of Moriori names. They are spoken by Charles Solomon, son of the last "full-blooded" Moriori. He did not, however, speak the Moriori language.
The "modern" list is of current Māori names, dating from 1835.
